title: 105_s2433
content: TITLE X--FINANCIAL INFORMATION PRIVACY PROTECTION is added to the Consumer Credit Protection Act to enhance financial information privacy. The Financial Information Privacy Act, under Title X of the Consumer Credit Protection Act, includes definitions for "customer" and "customer information of a financial institution." The Act aims to protect customer information maintained by financial institutions. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines "customer information of a financial institution" as information derived from the relationship between a financial institution and its customer. This includes any information identified with the customer, and the term "document" refers to any information in any form. A financial institution is broadly defined as any institution providing financial services to customers with credit, deposit, trust, or other financial accounts. This definition also includes depository institutions, loan or finance companies, and credit card issuers. The Financial Information Privacy Act defines "customer information of a financial institution" broadly, including data from the relationship between the institution and its customers. The Act prohibits obtaining customer information through false pretenses, with the term "financial institution" encompassing various entities like depository institutions, loan companies, credit card issuers, and consumer reporting agencies. The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System may further define "financial institution" through regulations. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits obtaining customer information from a financial institution through false pretenses, such as making false statements to deceive officers, employees, or customers into releasing the information. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits fraudulent statements or providing forged documents to deceive financial institution personnel into releasing customer information. It is also a violation to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses. The Financial Information Privacy Act prohibits fraudulent statements or forged documents to deceive financial institution personnel for customer information. It is also a violation to solicit someone to obtain customer information under false pretenses, except for law enforcement agencies and certain cases for financial institutions. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows financial institutions to obtain customer information for security testing, misconduct investigations, and information recovery. It also permits access to public record customer information under securities laws. The Financial Information Privacy Act allows financial institutions to access customer information available as public records under securities laws. Enforcement of compliance with the Act is done by the Federal Trade Commission, with additional enforcement by other agencies in certain cases. Compliance with the Financial Information Privacy Act is enforced by various agencies based on the type of financial institution, including the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve Board, and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. The Financial Information Privacy Act is enforced by different agencies depending on the type of financial institution, such as the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency, the Federal Reserve Board, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and the Office of Thrift Supervision for savings associations. Violations of the Act are treated as violations of other laws by the respective agencies. Violations of the Act are treated as violations of other laws by the respective agencies. States also have the authority to take action for violations of the Act. States have the authority to take action for violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act, including bringing actions to enjoin violations, recover damages, and be awarded costs and attorney fees for successful actions. States have the authority to take action for violations of the Financial Information Privacy Act, including recovering costs and attorney fees for successful actions. Prior notice must be served to federal regulators before taking action, and they have the right to intervene in the action if necessary. The Federal Trade Commission or an agency described in subsection (b) has the right to intervene in actions under the Financial Information Privacy Act, be heard on all matters, remove actions to the appropriate court, and file petitions for appeal. State officials can also conduct investigations and administer oaths for such actions. The chief law enforcement officer or designated State official can exercise powers to conduct investigations, administer oaths, and compel witnesses or evidence. States are limited in taking action if the Federal Trade Commission has initiated a civil action. Failure to comply with the Financial Information Privacy Act can result in civil liability for individuals not affiliated with financial institutions. Sec. 1005 of the Financial Information Privacy Act outlines civil liability for individuals not affiliated with financial institutions who fail to comply with the provisions of the Act. This includes liability for actual damages, additional damages determined by the court, and attorneys' fees in successful cases. Sec. 1006 imposes criminal penalties for violating section 1003, including fines or imprisonment up to 5 years. Enhanced penalties apply for aggravated cases involving violations of other laws or illegal activities exceeding $100,000 in a 12-month period. Sec. 1007 states that this title does not override state laws unless they are inconsistent, and if state laws provide greater protection, they prevail. Sec. 1008 requires Federal banking agencies to provide guidance to achieve the objectives of this title. Sec. 1008 mandates Federal banking agencies to issue advisories to depository institutions to prevent prohibited activities. The Comptroller General must report to Congress within 18 months on the effectiveness of the remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information. Recommendations for additional legislative action may be included. The report to Congress will assess the effectiveness of remedies in addressing fraudulent attempts to obtain financial information and provide recommendations for further legislative or regulatory action to protect financial privacy.
